_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ions Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Operations Manager is assisted by other Helena staff, as directed.  The Operations Manager is responsible for ensuring that Helena Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Prevention Program which includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigations, and Emergency Contingency Plans.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Helena's Madison, SD Facility is a non-responding facility. Helena has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There has been a single injury occur to a Facility Process Operator over the past five years.  Details of this incident are provided in Section 6.0 of this EPA RMP Report.

CONCLUSION

The Risk Management Plan implemented by Helena Chemical Company at the Madison, SD Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Madison, SD Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Lake County South Dakota LEPC and the Madison Fire Department.  

NOTE: Sections 4, 5, and 7 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Madison, SD Facility.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Helena Chemical Company (Helena) Madison, SD Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68. Standards codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration at 29 CFR 1910.119 are not applicable to the operations at this facility because the facility is operated as a retail operation and is exempt from the OSHA standards.  However, the OSHA standards at 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, are applicable and are included in the Risk Management Program (RMPr) document that is implemented by this Facility.

This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Madison, SD Facility located within Madison, SD city limits at an intersection along 3rd Street and 3rd Street SW in Madison, SD.  The physical address to the Facility is 620 SW Third Street, Madison, SD 57042.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Madison, SD Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Madison, SD Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.

PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP

Helena is submitting this because the Madison, SD Facility is ready for the EPA 5-year update.  All relevant sections for a Program 2 RMP Facility have been reviewed and/or updated.  The updates are reflected in both the EPA RMP Submit report and the Facility Risk Management Plan Program Document (RMPr).

FACILITY

The Madison, SD Facility is a retail agricultural chemical facility and operates one (1) covered process that includes Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is transported to the Facility via a commercial tanker truck (9,600 gallon) and then

transferred to one (1) 12,000-gallon stationary storage tanks.  The commercial tanker truck operator (Vendor/Contractor) performs these transfer operations.  

Helena stores the anhydrous ammonia in the on-site stationary storage tanks and then transfers the anhydrous ammonia from the storage tank to nurse tanks at point of retail sale to the end user (e.g. the farmer).  This Facility owns and operates (1) 1,000-gallon nurse tank, (5) 1,000-gallon double nurse tanks, and (5) 1,500-gallon double nurse tanks.  Helena performs this operation in accordance with its RMPr accident prevention program.  
 
OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for the single covered process that is operated at this Facility.  The covered process includes anhydrous ammonia Storage and Handling.  

The worst case scenario release for the Retail Facility assumes that all the contents in the largest single storage tank are released.  For this Facility, the largest vessel is a 12,000-gallon stationary storage tank.  The release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.

The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario was completed for the storage and handling covered process as well.  The alternative release for the Storage and Handling assumes a 30-second release from a ruptured 2-inch transfer hose caused by an impact from a vehicle or some other source on the liquid ammonia transfer hose during a loading or unloading operation.  Although this event is classified as an alternative scenario, even an accident of this type is unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (backflow check valve, emergency shutoff valve, and excess flow valve on the storage tank side of the bulkhead) and operating procedures that Helena uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.
